articles.headline: Honda Aims to Reclaim Its Luster
articles.snippet: After natural disasters last year and dreadful reviews of the revamped Civic, Honda is struggling to return to its former success.
articles.abstract: After natural disasters last year and dreadful reviews of the revamped Civic, Honda is struggling to return to its former success.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — When everything seems to be going wrong, hire Jerry Seinfeld, bring back Ferris Bueller and pray. And even then things might not improve all that much.

articles.headline: Android Phones Take a Power Trip
articles.snippet: In a world crammed with Android phones, HTC, Samsung and Motorola introduce three new models, each of them Verizon 4Gs.
articles.abstract: In a world crammed with Android phones, HTC, Samsung and Motorola introduce three new models, each of them Verizon 4Gs.
articles.lead_paragraph: You know the old techie joke, right? If you don’t like the Android phones on the market, just wait a minute.

articles.headline: Color the 1 Percent 99 Percent Conflicted
articles.snippet: Criticism of the wealthiest Americans has prompted reactions from guilt to outrage — and much puzzlement.
articles.abstract: Criticism of the wealthiest Americans has prompted reactions from guilt to outrage — and much puzzlement.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOON after the Occupy Wall Street encampment was set up at Zuccotti Park in Manhattan last fall, 26-year-old Ryan Quick told his father, Leslie C. Quick III, a financier, that he might drop by the site.

articles.headline: Taking Back Your Business
articles.snippet: Entrepreneurs who have seen the companies they sold hurt by bad management or a bad economy often get the urge to take back control.
articles.abstract: Entrepreneurs who have seen the companies they sold hurt by bad management or a bad economy often get the urge to take back control.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN late 2003, Judith M. von Seldeneck walked into her boss’s office with a bold proposition: sell me back my old firm for a lot less than you paid for it five years ago, she told him, and I’ll be on my way.

articles.headline: Youths Are Watching, but Less Often on TV
articles.snippet: Young people still watch many television shows, but they are streaming them on computers and phones to a greater degree.
articles.abstract: Young people still watch many television shows, but they are streaming them on computers and phones to a greater degree.
articles.lead_paragraph: Television is America’s No. 1 pastime, with an average of four hours and 39 minutes consumed by every person every day.

articles.headline: States Negotiate $26 Billion Agreement for Homeowners
articles.snippet: Nearly two million Americans could benefit from mortgage relief from the nation’s biggest banks, as part of a broad government settlement to be announced on Thursday.
articles.abstract: Nearly two million Americans could benefit from mortgage relief from the nation’s biggest banks, as part of a broad government settlement to be announced on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of painstaking talks, government authorities and five of the nation’s biggest banks have agreed to a $26 billion settlement that could provide relief to nearly two million current and former American homeowners harmed by the bursting of the housing bubble, state and federal officials said. It is part of a broad national settlement aimed at halting the housing market’s downward slide and holding the banks accountable for foreclosure abuses.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Shaila Dewan

articles.headline: A Wealthy Backer Likes the Odds on Santorum
articles.snippet: Few people played a more pivotal role in Rick Santorum’s victories in Minnesota, Missouri and Colorado than Foster Friess, a wealthy donor to conservative causes.
articles.abstract: Few people played a more pivotal role in Rick Santorum’s victories in Minnesota, Missouri and Colorado than Foster Friess, a wealthy donor to conservative causes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney and Foster Friess, a wealthy donor to conservative causes, were walking out of an event together a few months ago when Mr. Friess broke the news: After backing Mr. Romney for president four years ago, he was getting behind Rick Santorum this time around.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: Security Bills Bruised by Lingering Fight
articles.snippet: Legislation intended to help protect infrastructure from terrorists is hampered by fears of pressure from advocates who scored a victory against antipiracy bills.
articles.abstract: Legislation intended to help protect infrastructure from terrorists is hampered by fears of pressure from advocates who scored a victory against antipiracy bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ghosts of two doomed antipiracy bills hang over a new and unrelated issue on Capitol Hill: proposed legislation to help secure the nation’s nuclear plants, water systems and other essential infrastructure from hackers and terrorists.

articles.headline: Libya Struggles to Curb Militias as Chaos Grows
articles.snippet: The Arab world’s most sweeping revolution is foundering as the interim Libyan government seems to be paralyzed by its lack of power to control competing militias.
articles.abstract: The Arab world’s most sweeping revolution is foundering as the interim Libyan government seems to be paralyzed by its lack of power to control competing militias.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — As the militiamen saw it, they had the best of intentions. They assaulted another militia at a seaside base here this week to rescue a woman who had been abducted. When the guns fell silent, briefly, the scene that unfolded felt as chaotic as Libya’s revolution these days — a government whose authority extends no further than its offices, militias whose swagger comes from guns far too plentiful and residents whose patience fades with every volley of gunfire that cracks at night.

articles.headline: Surplus Surprises Michigan, but Is It Safe to Spend Again?
articles.snippet: After a $457 million surplus, Michigan officials must sort out whether the worst is really over, whether it is safe to start spending again, or whether a rainy day fund may be the prudent course.
articles.abstract: After a $457 million surplus, Michigan officials must sort out whether the worst is really over, whether it is safe to start spending again, or whether a rainy day fund may be the prudent course.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over most of the past decade, budget deliberations in Michigan have taken on a glum and familiar monotony: What do we cut now?

articles.headline: U.S. and Israel Split on Speed of Iran Threat
articles.snippet: An intense debate has erupted over when Tehran’s nuclear facilities will become invulnerable to an Israeli attack, and if economic sanctions need more time to work.
articles.abstract: An intense debate has erupted over when Tehran’s nuclear facilities will become invulnerable to an Israeli attack, and if economic sanctions need more time to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Amid mounting tensions over whether Israel will carry out a military strike against Iran’s nuclear program, the United States and Israel remain at odds over a fundamental question: whether Iran’s crucial nuclear facilities are about to become impregnable.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Greeks Reach Deal on Austerity to Meet Condition of Bailout
articles.snippet: After days of talks, Greek political leaders reached a deal Thursday to support a package of harsh austerity measures demanded by Greece’s financial backers in return for a bailout.
articles.abstract: After days of talks, Greek political leaders reached a deal Thursday to support a package of harsh austerity measures demanded by Greece’s financial backers in return for a bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Global financial markets received a reprieve on Thursday after Greek political leaders agreed to sweeping new austerity measures that should unlock the financing Greece needs to avert a potentially damaging default in March.

articles.headline: Mortgage Plan Gives Billions to Homeowners, but With Exceptions
articles.snippet: Under the settlement, nearly two million Americans could benefit from mortgage relief from the nation’s biggest banks.
articles.abstract: Under the settlement, nearly two million Americans could benefit from mortgage relief from the nation’s biggest banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: As state and federal authorities announced the details of their $26 billion mortgage settlement with big banks on Thursday, millions of American homeowners were hoping that this time they would finally get relief.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Julie Creswell
